PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains Tax,
Hidden Death Tax described as ``Capital Gains Tax after death'',
Gift Tax,
Increased Company Tax,
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject these tax proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care.
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985.
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence for report by 31 March 1986-

(a) the need for an area of land for the purposes of the relocation and co-location of the Army's School of Infantry and Infantry Centre, Artillery Training and for Army manoeuvres, having regard to strategic and training requirements appropriate to the Australian Defence Force, existing defence facilities and training practices in comparable countries;

(b) the availability of sites including existing Army training areas suitable for these purposes, whether in New South Wales or elsewhere, having particular regard to the availability of Crown Land, and having regard to the Army's needs and any countervailing public interest; and

(c) the adequacy and appropriateness of current procedures in protecting the rights of individual landholders and communities in areas where acquisition is contemplated, in providing for fair and prompt compensation, and in providing for appeal procedures.

I am raising this matter because it has become one of great importance and urgency in its own right. But more than that, it is important also because it is symptomatic of several wider disorders of government. That is the motivation behind the third part of the motion.

The Japanese have a classical saying, going back to their centuries of autocratic government by the shoguns, who, of course, were a military government backed by the samurai. That saying is kanson mimpi, which means `official exalted, people despised'. I shall repeat that, Mr President, because I think it is of some significance: Official exalted, people despised. If there was ever a clear example of an advancing case of kanson mimpi in Australia, it must be that of the proposed Army land grab, because over the last few years there has been such an extraordinary amount of evasiveness, double talk and official shiftiness as to make an inquiry by the Senate into the whole background of events and their motivation absolutely necessary. I raise the matter with the Senate in that light.

I am pleased indeed that the Opposition supports this matter. In all fairness, I must say quite plainly that the Opposition suggested definite improvements to my original motion, which I have used in their totality in the present motion. That has been done following consultation and agreement with the interest groups involved. Those interest groups, as honourable senators may know, have for some time been greatly upset and agitated by the whole question of the Army's manoeuvres in these directions, and particularly over the indecisiveness on this issue over a period of slightly over a decade, as I shall shortly outline. It is evident, on that basis, since the National Party and the Liberal Party support the motion, that the reference of this whole scandalous matter to a standing committee of the Senate, the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, will pass.

There is, as I have said, a broader issue: The whole question of why and how land is acquired by government, and how and why compensation is arrived at and finally paid to people. I would hope that in this reference in that third paragraph `the adequacy and appropriateness of current procedures in protecting the rights of individual landholders and communities' and `providing for fair and prompt compensation' will have due weight in the Committee's considerations.

The Australian Democrats have taken a previous initiative in this direction, through my colleague Senator Janine Haines, who introduced the Property Rights Protection Bill, as a private member's Bill, in May last year. This Bill was designed to deal with the problems of New South Wales coal rights owners who had these rights resumed in 1981. I quote the case from Senator Haines's speech in this way:

Recent events in New South Wales, following the enactment of the Wran Government's Coal Acquisition Act of 1981 are a case in point. In a simple and savage move, that Government declared that the historical rights of thousands of New South Wales freehold landowners to whatever coal might be found on or under their property, no longer existed.

No compensation was paid in this matter until four years afterwards. This has proved unsatisfactory to those affected. Obviously, some mechanism for the provision of fair and adequate compensation for this type of land acquisition must be found, and a preliminary investigation of this set up in my motion. Paragraph (c) is designed to restore to Australians some rights and some forms of defence against the depredations of exalted officials, who, indeed, despise the people to the extent that they are prepared, over long periods, indeed many years, to delay decisions over land acquisition, to change their minds after keeping property owners in suspense through those years and, in the end, to deny them proper compensation promptly paid. It is high time that that stopped, and it is a major part of my motivation in bringing forward this matter.

The Army land grab saga itself could make several excellent episodes of Yes Minister. For years the Army has been flitting uneasily from locality to locality, producing environmental impact statements and doing other portentious preliminary work-all of which, needless to say, has cost the taxpayer plenty. Everywhere that the Army has favoured a locality with its doubtful intentions, that has had catastrophic effects on the people of that region. Land values have plummeted; persons facing the need to sell for urgent personal reasons have not been able to do so; and farmers have seen little point in developing their properties by making constructive improvements. All these things are not good for the economy and are not good for Australia. I suggest that an investigation might show that the Army's requirements do not balance adequately against those other equity considerations.

Briefly, the chronicle of events in this regard goes back to 1974, now 11 years ago, when the Army decided to acquire 200,000 hectares at Colo-Putty for relocation of the artillery and infantry schools and for a manoeuvres area. The matter dragged on until 1977 when the Army chose Dubbo as a favoured site for the new training facilities and Cobar as a favoured site for manoeuvres areas. There was a further hiatus, a very leisurely one-only five years this time-until February 1982 when the then Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, and the New South Wales Premier, Mr Wran, ordered further studies of the Dubbo and Cobar areas. But then New South Wales Government departments suggested other areas, including Parkes, Forbes, Wellington, Broken Hill and for the first time, Orange-Bathurst as possible schools areas. The manoeuvres area requirement at that stage was two million hectares-rather more than the 200,000 hectares suggested in 1974 and considerably larger than some major European countries. Yet that was a serious proposition put forward by the Army and the Government at that stage.

At that stage naturally landholders in all those areas became agitated and their position became insecure. The value of their property was immediately affected. In April 1982 the Federal-State steering committee for army training facilities decided that land south of Cobar would be suitable for the manoeuvres area. Environmental consultants for the Army, Dames and Moore, announced that sites near Dubbo, Bathurst- Orange and Tamworth-Armidale were being assessed for training areas, thereby cutting a wide swathe across three separate New South Wales areas of productive farming land. In August four new manoeuvres sites near Cobar and Broken Hill were suggested by the New South Wales Government and in September an area near Bathurst-Orange comprising part of the area rejected in July was added to the New South Wales Government's proposals for schools area sites. In March 1985 the New South Wales Premier released recommendations on sites in order of preference: Singleton, Dubbo and Orange-Bathurst-Mudgee. A site north-west of Cobar was accepted by the Federal Government as a site for manoeuvres areas. In May 1985 Singleton and Dubbo were rejected by the Federal Government. Bathurst-Orange again became subjected to detailed environmental study as a site for the schools area. Consultants Dames and Moore were again engaged to study Orange-Bathurst and to make a preliminary study at Singleton. As honourable senators know, we had an election in 1984. During that campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was in the Orange-Bathurst area and, according to statutory declarations I have seen, he gave frequent assurances to people in that area that, whatever happened, there would not be an Army land grab in the Orange-Bathurst area.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't know what goes on at all, does he?

—I do not know. Either he knew or he did not know. The effect is the same. In spite of what the Prime Minister said at that stage, in spite of those clear assurances, we now find intentions again clearly centred on the Orange-Bathurst region where the Army, in spite of clear statements by the Government that it does not intend to use productive land, indeed now has its eyes on a very large area of highly productive area. The plan now is to take over 70,000 hectares of farm land which consists of some 99 properties. I am advised that the proceeds of production from 54 of them was worth some $5m in exports to this country last year in the form of fine and super fine wool for which there is a ready demand that exceeds supply. Thus is the Government's and the Army's idea of not taking over productive land.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me and the Australian Democrats quite crazy that we should even contemplate eliminating this whole productive area in a nation which is struggling with an appalling growth in our foreign debt and which needs every dollar of export income we can get. If one could see an urgent strategic imperative for this acquisition, if the world was going to come to an end if the Army did not get those 70,000 hectares of land at Orange-Bathurst and destroy those farms and the livelihoods of 99 families, one might be able to consider it. But is that the case? The next question to be asked is: Does the Army really need this land? I am advised that the Army already owns more than 1 1/2 million hectares of land in Australia and, through a variety of agreements with various State authorities, can get access to a further 2 1/2 million hectares of Crown land should that be required.

According to the latest defence statistics, there are 32,000 men in uniform in the Army. Compare this with another country. West Germany, for instance, has approximately 320,000 men in uniform. That is approximately 10 times the number of Australians in uniform. Of course, that is a situation that we would expect. West Germany is a major world power. In addition, under North Atlantic Treaty Organisation agreements, a substantial number of American soldiers are stationed in West Germany. I am advised that the total land area for all of the military training establishments in West Germany is less than 150,000 hectares, which is approximately one-tenth of the land over which the Australian Army has exclusive occupancy and approximately one-twenty-fifth of the land to which it can obtain access.

I wonder whether anybody could tell me or, more importantly, whether anybody will be able to tell the Standing Committee, why an army one-tenth the size of the West German army needs 10 times as much land for it to be able to train itself adequately. No one can suggest that the West German army is not one of the most efficient and best trained armies in the world. There is no suggestion that it cannot carry out its manoeuvres properly. Why then does Australia need 100 times the amount of land for each soldier that the West German army needs for each soldier that it trains?

The military has a firm obligation to justify publicly and to the Parliament not only its request for this additional land but also the continuing saga of hesitation and delay and the constant spending of money over and over again on environmental studies which, apparently, lead to no result. That would be the proper role of the Senate Committee. The Committee reference I propose would certainly provide the opportunity for the Army to justify its actions. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I suggest to honourable senators that that fact alone would be a clear reason for supporting the motion for the reference. If this land were not required as military land but for some other purpose such as a major project requiring public expenditure, the outlays of public moneys would need to be justified before either the Public Accounts Committee or the Public Works Committee. That is a sound practice, and it is one that the Parliament has insisted on. It should insist on a similar procedure in respect of the proposed acquisition of land by the Army.

I have looked to some extent at the statements being made by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, in regard to the acquisition of this land and the costs that would be involved. All I can say charitably is that the Minister appears to have been very badly advised. He keeps floating a figure of $120m, which in spite of inflation has remained unchanged over the years, as the cost of establishing this combined complex in the Bathurst-Orange area. On any realistic view, it is obvious that a figure nearer $500m would be closer to the mark. I am not saying that I am competent to give an accurate cost; plainly I am not, but I think I am competent enough to say that there is something wrong with the Minister's original figure. Again, if the Committee reference is agreed to, it will behove the Army to let the community and the Parliament know just what is involved and tell us how much money it wants to spend, and how it wants to spend it and not just give us a figure of $120m grabbed out of the air. As we know from various recent tax discussions, the Government is very fond of grabbing figures out of the air for which no justification can subsequently be provided. For instance, I refer to the figure which it claimed would be saved in social service costs by introducing identity cards. That figure really comes from fairyland. I suggest that the figure of $120m also comes from fairyland.

There are a number of other matters that I ought to mention. According to information obtained under the Freedom of Information Act from military records, the land at Orange is the least preferred area of the three areas in New South Wales which were originally considered for acquisition. That is a very mysterious situation which requires some investigation. The Army, in its preliminary assessments, inspected the Orange area and considered it to be unsuitable for its purposes. It said that further studies should be concentrated on the remaining two areas under investigation namely, Tamworth and Cobar. If the Army considered the land at Orange to be unsuitable for its purposes, that is another good reason why the Parliament should be able to examine the proposed acquisition and satisfy itself that the additional land acquisition is necessary and, if it is necessary, that it is land that can best meet the purposes that the military.

There is an important strategic consideration in this matter. It is simply whether or not the best thing to do is to train our Army in south eastern Australia. I cannot see any real perceived threat to Australia from either New Zealand or Antarctica. I would have thought that any perceived threat to this country-which is probably unlikely-would be more likely to come from the north and west of the country. I put that thought in the minds of our strategic planners when they come to consider where people should be trained and where it would be appropriate for them to gain experience in areas where they may have to operate. It might be considered that, as in other countries, a highly mobile, strong air capability, parachute-trained army which exercises regularly in the north and west of the country would be more appropriate. I just throw that thought in for what it is worth.

It is again a matter of public record that the Premier of New South Wales favours an extension of the present Army base at Singleton. I would like to deal briefly with that matter because I think it is vitally important. I have been told that one of the reasons why the Army does not like the new land it might get at Singleton is that some areas of the land are too steep. I have not heard any other reason. I suppose that it is worth observing that wars are not usually fought in terrain designed to provide maximum comfort and convenience to the defending forces. Instead of the steep terrain being a ground for rejecting that as a proposed base it might count in its favour. Again, I think there is a thought that it would be nice if this training area could be very close to convenient public transport. That is a matter that has a certain financial backing. Obviously we do not want an area which is too remote. I do not think that is a primary consideration; the strategic background against which our forces should be trained is a more important one.

There is already a large area at Singleton which is quite capable of expansion to do most of the additional work for a co-located infantry and artillery school. Whether co-location is necessary is another matter at which the Committee might look. It is certainly not the case at the moment. We have the infantry school at Singleton and we have a very small artillery training school-I gather a sort of officers' club-at North Head in Sydney where the only opportunity to fire off guns is substantially out to sea, and that is done from time to time. If 4,000 hectares of land were added to the present area-they are available for sale at Singleton-it would be possible for most, if not all, of our necessary artillery practice to be carried out.

It appears to me on the face of it that the Army probably does not need the additional land at all, that the proposed site is one which the Army itself regards as unsuitable and that the land at Singleton could be made available with very little disruption and disturbance to or opposition from the local residents, and that is very important. I do not think we can tolerate a situation in which the Army feels it has an open right simply to go into areas, bulldoze across whole areas, remove 90 farmers from their land and destroy $5m worth of export income for this country. If the Army wants to do that it will take a lot to convince me, for one, on that point. It is not necessary to take over those vast areas. The whole matter can be handled by an extension of the area at Singleton.

I have had representations from a large number of people, including local government, in that area. Those gentlemen and ladies who have come to me have pointed out that Singleton traditionally now is an army town and there is a good reason for its remaining so. It takes some time for the Army to identify itself with the community and to become a part of it, as it has done in Singleton, and that is a very valuable part of continuity in this matter. In other words, it is much better to locate the Army in an area where the people accept it, where it is part of the community, rather than to destroy all that and try to start off somewhere else. Apparently, the only difficulty at the moment is that we have 36 recently acquired North Atlantic Treaty Organisation weapons, M198 howitzers, only 15 of which are based in New South Wales, according to my information. I gather that the rest are to be based in Victoria, South Australia and Queensland. These are quite esoteric weapons. Apparently we feel we should have such state of the art capability, although I would have thought that longer range and higher capability missiles would replace them within a few years. But for the time being we have them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will probably replace them now.

—As the honourable senator has said, they will probably replace them now. The point is that Victoria, South Australia and Queensland do not appear to be moving towards acquiring large tracts of land on which to test these weapons. This is probably because the range of these weapons becomes massive only if they are equipped with rocket-assisted projectiles. We know already from tests in other countries that these guns work. Apparently they do. It is not really necessary to test them by firing off rounds oneself. The Army has a range where this can be done regularly. The bottom line on that is to inform honourable senators who do not already know, but I am sure many of them do, that every time a person fires off one of those rounds it costs $70,000. We are being told that the Army wants to take over land in Bathurst-Orange which is worth $5m a year in export income so that occasionally it can fire off missiles, which we already know work, at a cost of $70,000 a round. I do not think that is a very acceptable proposition either to this Parliament or to the Australian public, but that is basically, as I understand it, the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is room for the infantry school to be relocated at Singleton. Landholders in the area are prepared to sell up to 4,000 hectares of land, which would provide an area which was large enough to test fire the new, larger weapons extensively, but perhaps not to their full rocket-assisted range. But this is not done, in fact, in the NATO countries which already have this weapon. They rely on the fact that the gun has been tested and that it works. They do not want to play with it to its full extent themselves and I suggest that we should not have to either. It could not be expected to be tested at that range too extensively in this country either. I think that is a reasonable and sensible proposition the Army ought to accept. Having accepted that, the whole question of the artillery range being anywhere except at Singleton becomes a dead issue. I think that once that is established by the Committee or by any investigation, this whole disgraceful matter will resolve itself quite quickly. I would hope so.

I have to consider also the present infrastructure at Singleton. I think we cannot go along with the idea that we are going to destroy everything and build new things at a vast cost. I am informed that the infrastructure already located at the Singleton Army base is worth some $56m, a not inconsiderable sum of money. It is a fact that much of that building is very old and in need of replacement. I suggest if we have $500m to spend we might use a very small amount of that, perhaps $10m, a much more modest sum, in extensive upgrading of facilities at Singleton. In that way we would have a single, rational artillery school with reasonable expectations and an infantry school which are co-located. I think if we work basically along those lines we ought to get somewhere.

I know there are other speakers on this matter. I am glad that there will be because I think it is one of those matters which has been a public scandal, certainly in my State of New South Wales, for so long that it is time it was ventilated. The Army must not regard itself, as I feel the defence forces so often have done in the past, as a sort of organisation which is immune from any kind of public scrutiny or any kind of supervision. Because it is a defence force it does not have the right to go along and take over anything at whatever cost and spend money like water without any kind of supervision. That, I believe, even in the interests of efficient defence in this country, has to stop. I think the Army ought to answer some of the questions which I have raised in this speech. It probably can. If it can, so much the better. I am quite willing to be educated. I would have thought that at least what I have said might be a starting point from which we can operate. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently the Government does not intend to take part in this debate, which is rather strange. On behalf of the Opposition, I rise to support the motion that has just been moved by Senator Mason. This subject has been a problem for quite some time now. There have been growing fears over quite a large area of New South Wales, particularly in the central tablelands area, about what the Army and the Government is really up to, to use a colloquialism. The facts and the background have been fairly well canvassed by Senator Mason. I do not need to go over that ground again. I simply say that the Opposition has been aware of the issue for some time. Certainly in recent weeks there has been a revival of the issue by the Government with the reappointment of environmental consultants. The issue has become very alarming to a large number of people. Therefore, we certainly support very strongly the principle of an examination of this whole subject by a Senate committee because we believe that the Government has not been handling it in a proper way. It has unnecessarily alarmed large numbers of people. It does not seem to be able to make up its mind about exactly what it is going to do. It has been making a number of quite contradictory statements and has also taken contradictory actions.

SPEECH.PARA: On 11 September Senator Mason gave notice of a motion that the Senate should set up a select committee to study this matter. We were immediately attracted to that proposal in principle for the reasons which I have given. However, we believed that Senator Mason's notice of motion was too narrow in its terms of reference, in the scope that the committee should have and the matters it should investigate. We also thought that it was inappropriate to set up a special committee of the Senate to consider the matter. In our Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence we already have a perfectly good instrument to investigate the matter. The Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee comprises senators who have some special knowledge and interest in defence matters. It seems to be the appropriate body to investigate this question on behalf of the Senate.

As Senator Mason has said, we have had negotiations since then with his Party, the Australian Democrats. The terms of reference that are now proposed resulted from those negotiations. Senator Mason has now moved his motion in terms which have been agreed upon. It incorporates some very major amendments which were suggested by the Opposition. The present motion refers the matter to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. The terms of reference are very considerably broadened so that they do not have the narrow focus that Senator Mason's original terms of reference had.

Going through the various limbs of this motion, the first concerns the reference to the Standing Committee of the need for an area of land for the purposes of relocation and co-location of the Army's School of Infantry and Infantry Centre, for artillery training and Army manoeuvres. So there are three separate requirements for the Army, some of which may be suitably accommodated in existing facilities. Others may need new facilities. That is what this issue has been about. But as I have said, the Government seems to have been unable to come to grips with it and to make firm decisions. It has now been floundering around for the last two or three years. The problem has come to a head with the need to vacate the artillery training area at North Head. We clearly accept that. However, whether a completely separate area has to be established for that purpose or whether it can be combined with other facilities the Army has or which it may be able to acquire without creating the major problems associated with resuming productive land is another matter. We want a Senate committee to do the job which the Government has failed to do. We want a proper investigation of these needs. Secondly, we do not want this investigation to be confined simply to New South Wales, to which the Army has confined its investigations to date. There may be sound reasons for confining it to New South Wales but the question of whether or not it should be confined to New South Wales needs to be fully and publicly investigated and a Senate committee is the appropriate body to do that.

The second limb of this motion is the availability of sites, whether in New South Wales or elsewhere. The search should not be confined, as it seems to have been by the Government over the past year or so, to productive privately held land but should have regard to the availability of Crown land, not only in New South Wales but throughout Australia. Senator Mason has mentioned already that vast areas of land in other parts of Australia could be available if necessary. This whole search also raises the question of how much land is required, whether it be privately owned or Crown land. Again we have seen utter confusion on the part of the Government as to how much land is required.

Shortly after the election of the Hawke Government the then Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, announced that there would be an environmental impact study into the acquisition of 2.2 million hectares of land at Cobar for a manoeuvres area and also announced the study of the suitability of land in three different areas-Tamworth, Bathurst-Orange and Dubbo-for the schools complex. The areas around Dubbo and the central tablelands, including Bathurst- Orange, originally embraced the study of some 350,000 hectares, so that vast areas of land were included in this environmental impact study. That led to widespread outcries such that the then Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, on 23 July 1984 announced that the Government had abandoned these proposals and was seeking new recommendations from New South Wales.

In March of this year the New South Wales Premier, Mr Wran, announced that his Government had recommended a reduced area for manoeuvres at Cobar and suggested an area incorporating the existing infantry centre at Singleton in the Hunter Valley for the schools complex. In May this year the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, announced that a draft environmental impact study would be prepared for the Bathurst-Orange site for the schools complex. The New South Wales Premier spoke about Singleton and a couple of months later the Minister for Defence swung the concentration to Bathurst-Orange and announced that the Singleton and Dubbo areas had been abandoned. That is the position we are in now.

There have been considerable reductions in the area being looked at in the central tablelands; from the original 350,000 hectares to approximately 70,000 hectares. The area being looked at in the Cobar region has been considerably reduced as well. One has only to give a brief outline of what has been done by the Government over the past year or so to have great sympathy for the great concerns that have been expressed by so many landholders in New South Wales about the activities of the Army and the inability of this Government to come to grips with the problem.

There has been great and active opposition, in both the Cobar and Central Highlands areas and there has also been great concern in the Singleton area because the infantry school complex is already there. That area has a great infrastructure and Senator Mason has already referred to this. I agree that millions of dollars have been invested there. The Army recently expressed the view to a Senate Estimates committee that most of these complexes would have to be rebuilt; nevertheless the valuable sites are there and probably many of the present facilities could be retained. That seems to be a matter for debate and that again is another subject which needs to be properly investigated.

There is also great concern among members of the business community in Singleton itself about the effect on the town if the Army moved out of the area completely. These are major issues which cry out for proper and public investigation. That is what Senator Mason's proposal, which I am supporting, on behalf of the Opposition, is all about. If further proof were needed, there was quite a detailed examination of these questions at the recent Senate Estimates committee, particularly in questions from Senator Sir John Carrick, who, no doubt, will have something more to say in this debate this morning. Senator Sir John Carrick extensively questioned Army officers at those committee hearings and I must say that I was left with a greater unease about the situation as a result of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —An inadequate response.

—As Senator Michael Baume says, there were inadequate responses and we were left with the feeling that there was total confusion and uncertainty on the part of the Army, even after all the investigations. The Army seemed to be relying on this enviromental study and the enviromental experts to make its decisions. That is quite an incredible conclusion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has already put its attitude on the record. The former Minister for Defence and present shadow Minister for Defence, Mr Ian Sinclair, has made a number of public statements on behalf of the Opposition in relation to this matter. I wish to restate the principles which animate the Opposition's attitude to this whole question. Clearly we believe that the Army must have adequate training areas and that some of its existing facilities will have to be replaced. Clearly the North Head facility must be replaced and there may be some need to replace others. This is a matter which must be fully considered. Secondly, we feel that the Commonwealth and New South Wales Governments-and, indeed, interests that are wider than those in New South Wales-must look at the existing facilities and holdings of land and other areas of Crown land. Thirdly, we believe that productive farming land should be examined only as a last resort and that there should be the closest consultation with affected land owners in the matter, even before any environmental studies are embarked upon.

The third point of this motion is that there should be a study of the adequacy and appropriateness of current procedurers in protecting the rights of individuals and communities where acquisition is being contemplated. Fair and prompt compensation and appeal procedures should be provided. Under existing land acquisition rules I guess there are procedures for providing fair compensation. Whether it is prompt or not may be another matter, but if it is not prompt that is probably the Government's failing. There are appeal procedures, but clearly there are not at present adequate procedures for protecting the rights of individuals in areas where acquisition is contemplated. That is why all the people in this area have appealed to the Senate. They feel that they have not have been given proper hearings by either the Government of New South Wales or the Commonwealth Government. Clearly there is a need for proper avenues of consideration for these people who have been put in this plight by the needs of the Government. However, the way in which both the Government and the Army have gone about satisfying those needs leaves a great deal to be desired. For those reasons we support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason's motion proposes to refer to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence the proposed new Army training facilities in New South Wales. This is not a course which the Government will resist to the point of division, but I want to make it absolutely clear at the outset, as I will in the course of my remarks, that there is no justification for this inquiry and it will simply be a waste of time, money and energy for all those involved. The only imperative requiring an inquiry is the perceived political imperative of the Australian Democrats and the Opposition. An inquiry would simply serve to reopen in a highly politicised and not especially expert context very complex issues which have already been given very thorough and comprehensive examination on a technically informed basis, including issues which are the subject of a current environmental impact study. I think the political orientation of the proposed inquiry was made very obvious by Senator Mason in statements that he made early in September, reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 September, a good many of which he has repeated here today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason has expressed concern about three matters. First, he alleged that there were contradictions between statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the selection of an area near Orange for the Army schools complex. Secondly, he indicated that he was concerned about the size of the proposed Army training facilities in relation to the size of such facilities overseas. I shall return to both those matters later. The third issue that Senator Mason raised in his statement last month can be dismissed out of hand in that it demonstrates very clearly the political character of this enterprise. In one of the more preposterous statements that ever emanated from him-and that is a very large claim as there have been many competitors for that honour over the years-he suggested that one of the reasons for the establishment of the Army training facilities in New South Wales is to provide an alternative base for the United States in the event that the United States is required to withdraw from its bases in the Philippines.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said was that there were people in the Orange-Bathurst area who felt that way.

—The honourable senator wants to nurture those delusions because he is coming into this chamber and behaving in a way that is crude, vulgar, political and not deserving of serious minded attention by rational senators or anybody else. The land areas in question may well be used for joint exercises from time to time, but they are simply not capable of performing the roles of the United States bases in the Philippines. It is uninformed and ludicrous speculation. It is transparently, self-evidently politically motivated when put in the terms that it was by Senator Mason, both then and now.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason's motion is clearly couched in terms that are intended to attract the support of the coalition parties, support which it has received, not surprisingly, committed as those parties are to the hypocritical position which has been outlined by Mr Sinclair, the coalition spokesman on defence and Leader of the National Party of Australia. I shall come back to that. The issue of the new Army training facilities in New South Wales exhibits once again the yawning chasm between coalition rhetoric and the reality of its commitment to the defence of Australia in practice. Coalition members never cease to wrap themselves in the flag and to portray themselves as dedicated devotees of the defence of Australia, but their substantial performance is, and always has been, quite another matter. Their shortcomings are evident in the quality of their strategic analysis and in the level of budgetary outlays that they actually provided for defence in real terms under Fraser, compared with those levels provided by the Hawke Government. Once again, the issue that is presently before the Senate tests their commitment to the provision of adequate facilities for the Australian Defence Force in the face of localised pork-barrel politics. Once again the contrast between the Opposition's rhetoric on defence and its actual performance is starkly evident. The coalition parties, when in government, knew about the need for new Army training facilities in New South Wales at least as early as 1977. Nevertheless, as they did in so many other defence related areas, they dithered about for six years until they were voted out of office, mercifully for us all, in 1983.

Both the dithering of the coalition in government and its political hypocrisy now will be evident as I proceed to go through the history of the examination of the proposals for Army training facilities in New South Wales. That same account will establish the irrelevance and redundancy of the reference proposed by Senator Mason. Furthermore, I think it will become evident that those who seek to manipulate and exploit the concerns of those directly affected by the establishment of these new Army training facilities are engaging in political hypocrisy of the highest order. That hypocrisy is personified by the attitude of Mr Sinclair who, as the then Minister for Defence, approved a Press release in 1982 proposing the investigation of areas larger and richer than those that are presently the subject of the environmental impact statement. He then sat on that Press release when it became evident that an election was in the offing. Now in opposition he has adopted an unctuous and sanctimonious posture of opposition to proposals which are more limited than those which he proposed for investigation when he was the Minister.

Seeing the political opportunity, Senator Mason has now darted into the fray and proposes what I have already described as an expensive and redundant inquiry into whether the Army really needs the land, whether it needs it in New South Wales and all the other complex technical issues associated with balancing the training requirements of the Australian Defence Force with other public interests. Such an inquiry might have been appropriate some years ago. It is now quite properly to be regarded as an expensive waste of time. However, what it is likely to do-encouraged by the way in which Senator Mason feeds assiduously rumours, however lunatic, that circulate about some of these things-is arouse quite unwarranted public concern in the variety of areas in which this inquiry might choose to wander. So it cannot even be regarded with benign indifference as a kind of harmless diversion to keep the Democrats in their own playpen and away from the more serious preoccupations of state.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a few facts?

—I am getting to that. I have all this rhetoric here so I might as well. If it has any redeeming virtue it would be the possibility that the third aspect of Senator Mason's proposed terms of reference might yield something of desirable value, but in the highly political context in which this proposed inquiry would proceed even that must be regarded as highly unlikely.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed new Army training facilities in New South Wales have been the subject of an exhaustive process of investigation, including the current environmental impact statement which is to be completed next January. That exhaustive process began in the mid 1970s. Considerations of new arrangements for Army training facilities were motivated by pressures on three existing defence training facilities. First, under the Sydney Harbour foreshores agreement, it is necessary to transfer the School of Artillery from North Head in order to make that site available to the State of New South Wales, as was agreed in December 1978. Secondly, the training area at Holsworthy is under sustained pressure from urban development and its utility to the Army is under severe restrictions in order to control noise nuisance, bushfire damage and to reduce the risk to aircraft overflying from Mascot. Thirdly, Army facilities at Singleton were also subject to growing community concerns associated with increasing noise level as artillery training was transferred from Holsworthy to Singleton.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that why the locals want Singleton expanded?
—The honourable senator is now representing Singleton too, is he?
—I am just concerned with the facts, which obviously you have no concern for.

—He is a busy little chap, isn't he? These three major trends in the availability and utility of existing Army training facilities in New South Wales led to an examination of alternative possibilities in New South Wales in 1977. The examination focused on New South Wales for two simple reasons: Firstly, the existing facilities which needed to be replaced or supplemented were located in New South Wales; and secondly, both regular and reserve units which required the relevant forms of training were particularly concentrated in New South Wales. There was obviously no doubt in the mind of the Fraser Government that the need for training facilities was in New South Wales. After four years of examination of alternative locations, in 1981 the Fraser Government endorsed a formal consultative mechanism with New South Wales to develop the Army training facilities project. The extra costs and inefficiencies of going outside New South Wales have been obvious for eight years, but Senator Mason proposes that the Standing Committee investigate the availability of sites, including existing Army training areas suitable for these purposes, whether in New South Wales or elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason's motion also proposes a re-examination by the same Committee of the question of the area of land required for Army manoeuvres and infantry and artillery training, as he said:
`. . . having regard to strategic and training requirements appropriate to the Australian Defence Force, existing defence facilities and training practices in comparable countries'.

This is a matter which has already been given thorough, extensive and very careful consideration. In February 1982 the then Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, and the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, announced that investigations would proceed into new training areas at Cobar and Dubbo to, as they said, `enable the transfer of existing Army facilities from North Head and Singleton and reduce demands on the training area at Holsworthy'. Later that same year Tamworth and Bathurst-Orange were added to Dubbo as areas to be considered for possible location of the schools. At that stage the areas being sought were about two million hectares for manoeuvres and 160,000 hectares for the schools. However, the location which was to be studied near Bathurst-Orange as a possible location for the schools involved some 350,000 hectares. The Press release prepared for and cleared by the then Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, announcing, as I have already said, the investigation of these large and rich areas, was held up by him until after the March 1983 election when it was released jointly by the incoming Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, and the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran. What Mr Sinclair had approved as Minister for Defence-I do not think this can be forgotten and it bears repetition-he proceeded then to attack as Leader of the National Party in opposition.

On 23 July 1984, after considering a consultant's report, the Labor Government rejected the proposed areas near Tamworth, Bathurst-Orange and Dubbo as sites for Army training facilities. Cabinet also agreed that negotiations should be initiated with the New South Wales Government to identify an area in that State which would meet the following criteria:

The area should be one which is sparsely populated, has low economic potential, does not include prime agricultural land, contains no or few places of ecological or historical importance, avoids major disruption to the local population and satisfies Defence needs for suitable location, terrain and vegetation and would, with proper land management, be able to sustain continuous training activities.

Federal Cabinet then directed the Army to review its requirements, particularly as regards the size of the area of land required. It also requested the New South Wales Government to identify suitable locations. As a result of that further review and investigation in March 1985 Mr Wran offered a one million hectare area near Cobar for manoeuvre training and three options for schools at Singleton, Dubbo and Bathurst-Orange, each of the order of 70,000 hectares.

On 28 March 1985 Mr Kim Beazley, the Minister, announced that detailed studies would begin on an area north-west of Cobar to determine its suitability as a site for Army manoeuvres. The area to be studied was slightly smaller than that suggested by the New South Wales Government and excluded the natural gas pipeline to the south of the proposed area. Mr Beazley noted that the proposed manoeuvre area would include a 182,000 hectare firing range and was large and varied enough to allow large military exercises with live firing in certain areas in a wide variety of tactical situations. The manoeuvre area involved the acquisition of six properties for the live firing range and limited access to less than 50 other properties when required to carry out large scale manoeuvres. In the case of areas where only access was required it was determined that property holders would be able to retain and live on their properties.

On 9 May 1985 the Minister for Defence announced that detailed studies would begin on the suitability of an area between Bathurst and Orange as a proposed site for the Army School of Artillery and Infantry Centre. Senator Mason professes to be concerned about a possible contradiction between statements by the Prime Minister and other Government spokesmen to the effect that the original Bathurst-Orange site had been rejected as unsuitable for Army training purposes by the Federal Government; but there is, of course, no contradiction. The original 350,000 hectare proposal at Bathurst-Orange, investigation of which had been approved by Mr Sinclair as Minister for Defence, was rejected by the Labor Government because if its productivity and environmental significance. The site which has been selected for further consideration at Bathurst-Orange consists of 70,000 hectares of poor agricultural land west of Hill End which involves the acquisition of less than 100 properties. It is one fifth the size of the original Bathurst-Orange proposal and involves the acquisition of one tenth as many properties.

The New South Wales State Government's preferred option of an expansion of the existing Army facilities at Singleton was ruled out because of the precipitous and heavily timbered terrain which would mostly be inaccessible to vehicles and artillery. Furthermore, it was evident that useful expansion of the Army's existing base at Singleton would be in conflict with economic and social development of the area and much more costly than the Bathurst-Orange option. Furthermore, it would directly affect several hundred landholders and involve a substantial increase in artillery training which would exacerbate existing noise problems from artillery firing already developing in the area. The other alternative proposed by the New South Wales Government near Dubbo was rejected because it is relatively flat and heavily timbered and does not provide sufficient variety of terrain for worthwhile military training.

Both the Cobar and Bathurst-Orange proposals are now the subject of environmental impact studies which have been under way for several months. These environmental impact studies are being undertaken by professional consultants in full consultation with State and local authorities, community groups and, as far as is practicable, with all of the landowners involved. The environmental impact studies are being undertaken in conformity with the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The resulting environmental impact statement for Cobar is intended to be issued in December 1985 and the environmental impact study for Bathurst- Orange is intended to be released in February 1986. After public consideration and comment for three months final environmental impact statements will be prepared and submitted to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment for his consideration under the Act. Recommendations will then be made to the Government and decisions on both proposals will be taken.

These two proposals have been developed on the basis of a careful examination of `training requirements appropriate to the Australian Defence Force' and `existing defence facilities'-in the terms of Senator Mason's motion-and further examination in the manner proposed by Senator Mason would be utterly redundant.

The proposed terms of reference of Senator Mason's inquiry also refer to `training practices in comparable countries'. This element of his proposal is intended to draw attention, as he did today, to smaller training facilities in Europe and elsewhere. In this context it should be noted that the size of the training areas proposed in Australia is related to the ability of the land to regenerate after exercises. Land near Cobar is more fragile than that in Europe, which has a completely different ecology and hence its use is rotated. Furthermore, the Australian Army does not fire artillery over populated areas, which is a practice required by some of the smaller training facilities which Senator Mason appears to find so attractive.

While a major consideration in the selection of the land which is involved in the current environmental impact studies was the requirements of the Army for areas large enough and varied enough to provide adequate training, careful consideration was also given to countervailing public interests. The areas selected have been chosen, as I think I have indicated in sufficient detail to make the point, in order to have a minimum impact on landholders, prime agricultural lands, important mineral deposits and areas of environmental or cultural interests. The areas selected were chosen after very lengthy consultation with community groups, conservationists, local councils and the State Government. After eight years of investigation and consideration of the needs of the Army for new training facilities in New South Wales, Senator Mason now seeks to reopen the entire issue to re-examine whether the training facilities are needed and whether they are required in New South Wales. No doubt, as I have said, he expects to derive some political advantage from this enterprise, but from any public policy vantage point or public interest vantage point it can be regarded only as a monumental waste of time.

The final aspect of Senator Mason's proposal addresses the question of safeguarding the rights of landholders, including adequacy of compensation and provision of appeal procedures. In terms of the protection of the rights of landholders, the Premier of New South Wales made it clear in March 1985 that the State Government would insist upon the development of a proper land management plan for areas in which access was required for Army manoeuvres. This land management plan will require adequate advanced warning to landholders, no undue disturbance of the land, fair and reasonable compensation for any damage and proper arrangements for bushfire prevention.

In so far as compensation for any land which is acquired is concerned, this is both a firm government policy commitment and, or course, a constitutional requirement. There is no question of fair and adequate compensation not being provided.

I repeat that there is no evident justification for this inquiry. It comes at the end of a protracted period of investigation of the need and of the alternative means of meeting that need, and the interests it seeks to safeguard are already adequately protected and will be adequately protected. It is totally unnecessary, and its lack of necessity will, the Government is confident, be amply demonstrated after all the effort and expense of the new inquiry has been incurred. If the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party and the National Party, for crude political reasons of their own, want to combine their resources and force a reference upon the Committee, this is not a course which the Government can usefully resist. We have made our position, I think, amply and abundantly clear. We do not believe that there is any justification for the inquiry. We believe it will prove to be a complete and utter waste of time and taxpayers' money. But lest it be thought that we are seeking somehow to avoid scrutiny, and lest it be thought that we have anything to hide-which we do not-the Government will not, as I indicated at the outset, pursue that opposition to the point of division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a proposal to make a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence regarding the proposed acquisition of land by the Department of Defence for an Army base. The reference seeks to discover the facts on three particular lines of inquiry. The first is the need for an area of land for the purposes of relocation and co-location of three matters: First, the Army School of Infantry; secondly, the Artillery Training Centre; and thirdly, a manoeuvre area. Secondly, the reference seeks to inquire as to the availability of sites existing as Army training areas throughout Australia, and in particular whether Crown land is available which could be of use. Finally, it looks to the adequacy and appropriateness of procedures for protecting individual rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans has said that there is no justification for such an inquiry. If one were looking for justification, one would have taken his speech and compared it with the very many statements which have been made by the Government, and governments of other States, and promises made to the people of Australia. The very need for this is based upon the confusion of information that has been presented to the people. I propose to demonstrate that very clearly.

Fundamentally, we are looking at three matters. We are looking at the need, or otherwise, for a relocation of the Infantry Training Centre. That centre is presently at Singleton. What is needed to be asked is: Is it inadequate? Is it geographically the wrong place? Are the nature and the contours of the ground around it wrong for infantry training? Senator Evans says that the evidence is clear. However, there are on record statements by senior Army officers, who have been engaged in this very training, that the Singleton area is an ideal area for infantry training. That seems to suggest that there might be a need for an inquiry and some disputation of facts on this matter. Secondly, it has been said that the infrastructure that exists in Singleton is of such a massive nature and is such a massive investment that one would have to have very good reason indeed to want to move to a completely virginal area and set up a new infantry training area.

Where have I heard the Minister refer to the fact that there in Singleton exists the whole infrastructure, the whole area of sewerage, drainage, electricity supply, plumbing to the area, and some 200 houses for the Army? Is it suggested that it is a light thing that one should put those all aside and go and seek somewhere else? Where is there evidence to prove that it is wrong to look to the capital value of all the access roads and bridges that are in Singleton? These would have to be built, in their tens of millions of dollars, elsewhere. I include also protection of the flood plain which separates the civilian community from the Army and gives a desirable environment.

I did not hear Senator Evans refer to some very significant things. He was the Minister who was present at the recent hearings of Senate Estimates Committee E. He will recall that he supplied evidence that the estimates for the Defence Department this year would contain between $350m and $400m-they are his figures-for devaluation and, therefore, the overall money for defence this year showed not a 10 per cent nominal increase but only a 3 per cent increase and, taking inflation into account, a decrease. He will recall that there was a very elaborate and lengthy discussion on why the Army could not afford to bring about the Waler project to provide new armoured personnel carriers for the protection of the soldiers of this country and that we have to look to the dilapidated and, indeed, dangerous carriers that the Auditor- General spent a great deal of time discussing. It seems to be a matter of no importance at all that we are willing to spend enormous sums of money relocating at the whim of some politician whilst we have not enough money to do the essential things to protect our soldiers and to give our soldiers mobility. If ever there were justification for testing how much this new proposal will cost, it is that it has been said that we cannot afford the Waler project-we cannot afford to equip our soldiers with mobility which is, first of all, safe and weapon-proof and, secondly, much better than the deficient APCs that the Auditor-General has seen fit to criticise and that he says may well be of no use.

No justification has been given for picking up the huge infrastructure at Singleton. The integration of the community and the Army has been described in sociological terms as very important not just for commercial purposes but for the whole social structure of the area. Indeed, lest anyone has any doubts about this matter, in the Estimates Committee I asked the Defence Department whether there had been an estimate of the cost of rebuilding Singleton. The response, which is not in Hansard yet, was:
A detailed estimate has not been made of the cost of rehabilitating facilities at Singleton for the infantry centre. However, a broad assessment had put the cost in the order of $30m.

That is not hundreds of millions of dollars, but $30m-not even the value of building those 200 houses elsewhere, because they would cost more than $30m to relocate. Now we know a very important thing indeed, and Senator Evans has the gall here today to say that there is no justification at all for an inquiry into this matter to try to save money that perhaps we could use to build better armoured personnel carriers for our soldiers.

It will be recalled that in the Estimates Committee one of the defences made was that Singleton had to go because there was a coal seam under it. I found that very fascinating indeed when I read Premier Wran's Press statement of 12 March this year. Premier Wran is, of course, the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, the Party in government. What did Mr Wran say? Knowing of coal seams, he said:
The State Government strongly believes that the schools complex should go to an enlarged Army base at Singleton.
There was no question of coal seams. Yet that was raised here in the Senate as a reason for shifting. The Premier of the State, negating that, went on to say:

This is because the Singleton site already has an Army base. It would involve mainly Crown land and conditional use of 19 properties to the south-west of the base. No properties in the vineyard, agriculturally productive or coal areas would be affected.

It is said that there is no justification for an inquiry. Yet the evidence given here by the Defence Department was that one of the reasons was the coal areas. If there were a need for justification, we found it in Senator Evans's speech.

I happen to have had some little experience of the Singleton camp. I know of the nature of its geography. Having crawled over a fair bit of it, I know that it is ideally suitable as an infantry training area. I am aware that its barracks and living quarters need upgrading. That in itself is a minor thing. Bear in mind what the Defence Department said after we put it under pressure: We could upgrade Singleton to a modern infantry training area for $30m, whereas to relocate elsewhere would cost at least $200m, $300m or $400m, quite apart from the disruption caused. Again it is said that there is no justification. Senator Evans cannot have escaped the fact that there have been widely circulated some 10 or 12 copies of statutory declarations made by people of the central west of New South Wales, the Bathurst-Orange-Dubbo area, saying that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had given them an unequivocal promise that there would be no Army base in the Bathurst-Orange area. Yet is there no justification for an inquiry? The facts are there. After all, Senator Evans says that we have already got the expert details on this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who promised?

—The Prime Minister of this country is documented in some 10 or 12 statutory declarations-I take it that nobody is doubting their veracity; if so, why does he not challenge them?-as saying emphatically that there would be no base in Bathurst-Orange. Everybody knows the reason for this sudden change. Senator Evans said: `All the technical details were there. It was to have been 120,000 hectares but we chopped it down to 70,000 because it fitted the bill'. What nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason Bathurst-Orange is now put forward, it being the least desirable area according to the impact studies and the one that was rejected previously, is that in the 1970s the Whitlam Government, under one more of its misconceived and misbegotten plans, set up a Bathurst-Orange development corporation that now has around its neck a debt of $90m. What is happening is very simple. This Government is using the Army base to bail out the debts of the Whitlam Government. No decision has been made in terms of what Senator Evans says are precise military means. When I asked the Army whether it was a fact that this proposed site was under a regular flight path and whether there would therefore be any danger from an artillery range, the Army said: `We must ask the environmental study people about that'-not the technical experts, not the artillerymen and not the defence people, because of course they know that it could not be more wrongly sited. Is there no reason, no justification, for an inquiry into this matter?

When I asked the Defence Department where its land was around Australia, I got a list. The Minister, having seen it, has agreed to its incorporation in Hansard. It shows that in Australia there is 1,082,700 hectares of Army land in 23 major locations. For example, in Shoalwater Bay in Queensland, there are 274,000 hectares. In Yampi in Western Australia there are 556,000 hectares. I seek leave to have the list incorporated in Hansard.
