SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am indebted to Senator Short for pulling together some of the strands in the debate-one strand silly, the other sensible. Perhaps I can deal with them one by one. First of all, if he wants to assist me I do not think he will do it by making speeches such as that. He said that I, the present Minister, agreed with many of the things that had been put by his side of politics. I think that is presumptuous in the extreme. I put it that the Opposition is starting to agree with what I have been saying for the last two and a half years as it gradually gets its act together. That is quite apparent if we look at the debate which has taken place on industry policy in this chamber over the last two and half years and on a wider variety of other matters. When the Opposition gets its act together on issues such as wage fixation, taxation and a whole range of other matters, perhaps the debate in the chamber will get better still. I genuinely compliment honourable senators on the contributions to the debate on the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Bill 1985 and the Bounty (Agricultural Tractors and Equipment) Bill 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal first of all with Senator Short's last little piece of rhetoric, which was a set of assertions rather than arguments. He accused this Government of being anti-business. He said that the tax package was anti-business. I suppose he justifies that by the Government's assault in the tax package on fringe benefits, because that is the burden of Question Time here from the Opposition-concern about the removal of entertainment deductions and things of that kind. The very important things about the tax package which Senator Short chose to ignore are the simple facts that this Government, in the tax package, has dealt with two issues which the present Opposition talked about for 27 out of the last 30 years in government and did nothing about; that is, the double taxation of dividends, the importance of imputation and the importance of dealing with the situation where funds in this country were being siphoned off because of all sorts of distortions in the tax system, into Surfers Paradise flats and things of that kind-into the property market and not into industry-and, of course, the very important question of the marginal taxation rates. Those are the two important elements which will be of long term benefit to industry in this country.

I do not have the particular quotation in front of me but, I think on 19 September in an editorial in the Australian Financial Review, the point was simply made about the tax package that for the first time in many years the stock exchange will become the most important vehicle for marshalling equity capital in this country. It went on to say that the capital gains tax which had been announced by the Government removed a tremendously important distortion in the taxation system which had been detrimental to industry for a long time. Senator Short cannot have it every conceivable way. The sooner the Opposition learns that under its new leader, the better. It cannot have free lunches and all these things that it wants, which are apparent from the way it asks questions here in Question Time about the taxation regime announced by the Government, and it cannot do these things, which are very important to industry, at the same time. It cannot have all those things at once. I find it extraordinary that the Opposition should come in here and talk about this Government making very little dint in unemployment. My God, look at who created it in 1981 and 1982 because of the total failure of a wages policy, apart from anything else. Those are some of the issues which I think the Opposition seriously has to address. It should not go on with this rhetoric about the Government's anti-business stance.

On the other hand, I think Senator Short made some very serious points about industry policy, which I know has been a matter of interest and concern to him for some time. He did that by asking a series of rhetorical questions which, at the end, he answered by saying that there is no easy answer to them. The essential question was: `How can we make industry more competitive?'. As Senator Short said, there is no easy answer; there is a complex of answers and a complex of policies which are relevant to answering that basic question.

On one particular aspect Senator Short joined issue with Senator Siddons on something that had been said by him. Senator Short asked these sorts of rhetorical questions: Can we say we need low or high technology industries? Can governments or bureaucrats achieve such accuracy? Can the private sector even achieve such accuracy? Should we be applying or producing better technology? The last question was asked relative to the bounty on machine tools. If we look at the total assistance package in respect of the computer industry, robotics, machine tools and so on, the answer of the Government is quite clear: We should be both applying and producing better technology. We do not see them as being in the alternative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.
—That is what the honourable senator said.
—No, I did not.

—I am sorry, but that was the rhetorical question the honourable senator asked. The answer is that we should be doing both. That is why minimum rates of duty have been brought in in respect of all those pieces of equipment which I mentioned which are central to any industry regeneration in this country. That is why a bounty was recommended and prescribed in respect of these industries, and indeed extended to exports. It is in these areas that we have to support our industries and we have to do it on a basis which will not have adverse downstream effects.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short also took Senator Siddons to task on that series of rhetorical questions about so-called picking winners. The picking winners debate in Australian industry policy is extraordinary, confused and very difficult. I contribute to that. I find it a very difficult question and I do not think any of us-I can only speak for myself-have all the answers on that issue. There are two diametrically opposed points of view. Senator Short says that we should not pick winners. I particularly quote from his speech at the Liberal Party Conference earlier this year, when he said:

Who would do the targeting? Inevitably governments and bureaucrats. But how can these people pick particular industry winners better than the market place? They cannot, as history has proved time and time again.
That is a good statement of a particular position on this issue. But he went on in the next paragraph to say:
There can be very little room any longer for policies which merely serve to prop up ailing industries with doubtful long term prospects.
If I might say so, that is a straight transposition into a winner picking exercise-

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Yes, because who makes the judgment about that? It is exactly the same people-the bureaucrats, the sorts of people the honourable senator talked about before. Which are the ailing industries? Who makes that judgment? Bureaucrats do. Later, in the same speech, the honourable senator again addressed that question but in a slightly different form. Perhaps I do not need to go through that now.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of picking winners is very difficult. Senator Puplick gave us a little lecture last night about the evils of picking winners, but five minutes earlier he referred to important reports by the Australian Science and Technology Council, on machine tools and robots; I forget the other matter, but both ASTEC reports were on the same general subject matter. Those reports advocated special investment allowances and a number of industry policy remedies to encourage the use of these tools in Australian industry. Senator Puplick chastised the Government. What a pity it was, he said, that the Government did not see fit to act on the ASTEC suggestions. Five minutes later he was giving us a lecture about the evils of picking winners in terms of industry policy.

I am not attacking Senator Puplick about that. Everyone who talks about this issue does the same thing, including me. I am just saying that it is a very difficult area, and one in which any of us should be very careful about being too prescriptive and too ideological. I am not talking about being politically ideological but being ideological in terms of industry policy on these matters. Everywhere that one hears people talking about this issue there are very great inconsistencies. Senator Siddons displays much greater clarity of mind on the issue than the rest of us. He is quite sure that we should pick winners, and he goes on to say why.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he think Siddons Industries is a winner?

—Of course it is a winner-look at its recent performance-and probably for many of the reasons that Senator Siddons advocated in terms of particular policy prescriptions. It is important for me to refer to what Senator Siddons had to say. He began by talking about the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Japan. MITI is the great maker of international industry policy dreams. It is said to have been immensely successful. It is said to be the arch winner picker of the world; it is the one that picks all the winners. If one talks to people in MITI about it, one finds that they have a little less enthusiasm for their success than probably even Senator Siddons does.
—The policy is to play it down.

—I know; but let the honourable senator ask people in MITI whether they have ever made any mistakes about picking winners. They will say: `Yes, we have made a few mistakes. We told Honda that they should not build motor cars. We are inclined to concede now that that may have been a mistake. We also thought that we had persuaded Sanyo not to go into consumer electronics. We now concede that that might have been a mistake'. They have a list of those sorts of things.
—There inevitably will be mistakes.

—Of course there will be mistakes. All sorts of things are said about MITI-that it allocates vast dollops of money all over the place to support and encourage industries, and so on. I do not think that that is correct at all. The crucial thing about MITI is its success as a co-ordinating department. One of the great successes of Japanese industry has been its flexibility and the attention which the financial system and the banks have given to supporting Japanese industry. It is in that context, of course, that the steps taken by this Government to deregulate our banking system and the financial sector will be of very great benefit to industry in the longer term, because much more competitive packages will be available to industry than we have ever had in this country previously. That is something that the Japanese banks have been providing for a very long time.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons made a very positive point about the importance of co-ordination between Government and industry. I agree with that point entirely. He would describe the Industries Assistance Commission as being confrontationist. I think that the effects of the IAC's work over a long period have produced that environment. It is sometimes an unfair characterisation-understandably, perhaps-of the IAC's role. It is very important to consider what that role is. Fundamentally, it is, first, to expose to public scrutiny the different levels of assistance, inputs and so on given to various industries, in the interests of public examination of those matters. Secondly, I think that a very important part of the IAC's role is to look at the question of overall resource allocation across the broad spectrum of productive activity in Australia. They are very important matters. It may be that the way in which the Commission has interpreted that role has led to perceptions of a confrontationist position-which I fully understand-but I do not think that one can dismiss the IAC's role entirely.

However, Senator Siddons made a very important point about the need to co-ordinate industry and government activities and, of course, to involve the work force in that process. He has been a very strong advocate of industrial democracy. I do not necessarily agree with Senator Siddons's details of the methods by which he would arrive at these sorts of solutions, but the idea that the work force has a stake and a share in the industry and should be part of the consultative process in respect of an industry, is very important indeed. One of the great tragedies of the Australian industrial relations scene, which has been detrimental to industry, is that for many years employers-not employers such as Senator Siddons was, but others-never felt it necessary to involve unions and employees in discussions about the importance of profits in industry. They never felt it necessary to do that at all. Why did they need to do so? It was said that it was not the business of the employees to know what profits are for and what they are spent on, or their business to understand the functions of profits in industry. I know; I worked in this area for a long time. That was always said. That has been a tragedy for this country, because the legacy of that sort of thing has been immensely damaging.

Only recently are some of these things starting to be understood. We grew up in an industrial relations climate in which people saw that, say, their company made $60m profit and they thought: `We ought to have a bit of that too; we work here'. That is a perfectly understandable reaction. The function of profits in an enterprise was not considered a subject which should be seriously addressed with unions and the work force.

I say to Senator Siddons that we as a government, because we happen to believe in the importance of the discussion of these matters and in co-ordination in relation to them, have established a series of industry councils, in various industries, which I think have been very helpful. One makes slow progress in these sorts of bodies-slow progress in bringing about attitudinal changes and understandings of the kind which Senator Siddons and I, I believe, would both regard as being important. But each of those industry councils has been working for a year now preparing what they call a stocktake of their industry. That involves looking at the strengths and weaknesses in a particular industry area. The sorts of things which are being identified are very interesting, right across the spectrum. Union misunderstandings about certain things, bad management, lack of marketing skills, and those sorts of things, which are all pretty accurate and which are being identified in that consultative process. It is painstaking; it is difficult; but in the important task of bringing about attitudinal change from the old confrontationist approach, which screwed up industry in this country, that process is tremendously important.

I want to give Senator Siddons one or two examples of this process at work. Twelve months ago the Australian shipbuilding industry was legitimately written off by most not particularly well informed commentators. Nearly every major shipbuilding yard in that industry today is almost in the position of turning away work. The industry has a lot of work to do-partly because of Government policy; we made some concessions to the industry in various ways, such as extending the bounty for exports and knocking off the iniquitous 2 per cent revenue duty on imports for that industry, and a number of things. We did that conditionally on an understanding about the future of the industry with the shipbuilders and unions. All I can say is that today the sorts of demarcation disputes which bedevilled that industry are very largely being resolved-it is not over yet; we cannot claim any degree of perfection-and employment in the industry has grown by 5 per cent in the last six months and will continue to grow. The sort of thing I am putting is possible if the right approaches are made. I am saying that I share many of Senator Siddons's views. The difficulty is to express that in concrete terms and to bring about the necessary incentives to change attitudes and so on in relation to these matters. Much the same sort of comment could be made about the steel industry. There are all sorts of problems associated with particular industries, but much the same sort of general observation could be made about the steel industry as a result of the changes which have been brought about by this Government.

If I might say so, having agreed with many of Senator Siddons's assumptions and sharing many of them, I really think we have to be a little less simplistic about the success of the Japanese industrial experience. The first thing I remind him of is that Japan is a factory. It is a manufacturing island-the most successful factory in the world. It has no other resources. It has not been deluded over many years into believing that its future may lie in some other Eldorado such as the last Government promised us with the mineral booms and so on. It is not deluded into believing that its future might lie on the sheep's back or things of that kind. It has never deluded itself about things like that over the last 100 years. Japan is a manufacturing island and is totally dependent on a manufacturing culture, something we have never had here. I think it is not quite correct to say that Japan has adopted a strategy of treating its workers differently and involving them in decision making. There is a lot of truth in that, but there are two views about that. I commend to Senator Siddons a not uncritical reading of the book Japan in the Passing Lane about the Toyota manufacturing company. I commend to him a reading of a book by an Australian resident in Japan, whose name I forget, entitled Bonsais to Levis. They are very important books. There is a whole range of them about Japanese manufacturing culture. The honourable senator has been to these establishments in Japan, as I have. I do not think we will ever reach the stage in Australia of people doing 5BX during tea breaks rather than having a cup of tea. I do not think it is possible to reach that stage because of very profound cultural differences. Of course, the Americans have locked themselves into a vast industry of literature in trying to work out where they went wrong and the Japanese went right. In the United States there are these extraordinary developments such as quality control circles. Nothing is done about them in the United States, they are taken to Japan, Japan develops them to a perfect art form and now they are going back to America and coming to Australia. All these things are happening and the American literature is full of discussion about the Japanese success. I think I can summarise all that literature by saying that a great variety of reasons, in terms of the general industrial environment, the financial environment, but, very importantly, the cultural environment, has led to much of the success of Japanese industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taiwan could equally be called a manufacturing island. It has not had much success.

—That is a topic I would sooner not embark on because I am not xenophobic about these things, but in terms of industry policy I might be if I started talking on that subject. Interestingly enough, I think the Japanese word which best describes the success of its industry policy is `huan' which means a notion of harmony in industrial relations, in enterprise success and so on, which I think has been immensely important to Japan. I share Senator Siddons's views about some of these issues. I am not yet in my mind persuaded that one should go to the winner-picking strategy that he advocates with the same precision that he advocates. I think it very important to think of industry policy, not so much in terms of picking winners in products and firms but in terms of what one might call the strategic approach. The strategic approach to industry policy is the one which a country like Sweden has. Sweden is not a country which targets or picks winners. Sweden's industry policy is to determine which major areas of industry it is going to be in and to make sure that the infrastructure for those things, the research base and all the things which government properly provides as ancillary to and supportive of industry are set up not only for 1985 but for 1995 as well.
—If we could do that in Australia it would be a start, wouldn't it?

—I agree. There is a lot to be said for that view. If I might say so with respect to honourable senators who have spoken, I am putting only another confused view about picking winners. I regard every view that has been put on this topic as being fairly confused and myself as being no exception to that process, but I think it is an important issue in the debate which has taken place and one which has to be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney said much the same as Senator Short. At some stage he addressed all the wider issues which we often talk about here and attacked the accord mark 2 as a shocking burden on industry. It is easy to do that. The alternatives are horrendous to comprehend. He gave a speech which I think was based on a Press release which he put out a week or so ago after Rank Industries Pty Ltd in Sydney collapsed and which one journalist unkindly described to me as Friday's bubble and squeak. I think it was, because in that release, after initially saying that the Rank company had collapsed because of inadequacy in the dumping laws and having found that that was not so, he suggested a number of other reasons why it had collapsed. All those reasons have some legitimacy about them. If we lived in a perfect world we would have no State government charges impacting on industry and no Commonwealth Government charges. We would have lower wages. We would produce a whole lot more goods and have nobody to sell them to. I do not think it is necessary to deal with many of the things to which Senator Chaney referred because we could go on for the life of this Parliament, and the next I suppose, debating the validity of the Government's approach to wage fixing policies and so on and it is not a matter I want to pursue here at great length.

As I understand it, honourable senators are generally supporting the legislation in relation to the machine tool industry with some criticisms or rhetorical questions. I come back to the tractor bounty legislation and to what Senator Short said. I have a lot of sympathy with his view. It is a view which would not however be put if we were talking about a tariff rather than a bounty. I think that is probably true. There are two basic means of traditional industry assistance in Australia-the tariff and the bounty. I am not criticising the honourable senator; I have some sympathy with the view. He asked: Because Chamberlain John Deere Pty Ltd has been assisted by a bounty for 63 years, why should the taxpayers' money continue to be spent on this industry which has not performed particularly well? Had it been a tariff I do not think he would have addressed it in quite the same way. I think that some distinction can be drawn there.

We had some difficulty in this package in resolving the questions which have ultimately been resolved in the legislation in its present form. We were very conscious that Chamberlain John Deere was making some changes to its company structures. For that reason, we extended the higher level of bounty for the next two years. In extending the bounty at the other end of the scale to 1992 instead of 1990, as was recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission, we were again concerned about questions of continuity in relation to this company's operations. I say to honourable senators that I would not have agreed to this proposal at all if it had not been for the fact that this company is the only significant manufacturer of tractors in this country. I do not think that I would approve a proposal for any other industry in similar circumstances in the way that we have done here. I think that is important.

We made a judgment on it; we may well be wrong. All that Opposition senators are saying is: `We are a bit critical of your judgment. We do not dislike Chamberlain John Deere'. They cannot say that they dislike Chamberlain John Deere. One of the difficulties in making any speeches on industrial policy is that one cannot say things like that. It was just a matter of judgment about what we should do, and it may be that we were wrong. I think that we were right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In relation to the Bounty (Agricultural Tractors and Equipment) Bill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, sub-clause (1), definition of `terminating day', leave out the definition, insert the following definition:
` ``terminating day'' means 31 December 1990 or such later day, not being a day later than 30 June 1991, as is fixed by the Minister by a notice published in the Gazette before 31 December 1990;'.
(2) Clause 12, sub-clause (1), leave out paragraphs (a), (b) and (c), insert: `an amount equal to 25 per cent of the value added to the tractor by the manufacturer.'.
(3) Clause 12, sub-clause (2), leave out paragraphs (a), (b) and (c), insert: `an amount equal to 25 per cent of the value added to the cab by the manufacturer.'.

All of the amendments relate to points which were raised in the second reading debate. The first amendment refers specifically to the period for which the bounty is payable. The effect of the amendment is to reduce the period of the bounty from now to 1992 from now to 1990; in other words, it will reduce the period by two years. The second amendment relates to the imposition of a uniform bounty of 25 per cent of the value added by the manufacturers for the whole of that period, as against the Government's proposal, to allow a higher rate of bounty for the first two years. The third amendment simply relates to the value added to the cab by the manufacturer. Essentially, the Opposition is seeking to reduce the period of assistance granted by way of bounty under this legislation and to reduce the bounty to 25 per cent for the whole of the period of the bounty scheme.

I think that I should clear up a couple of points which were raised in the second reading debate by Senator Siddons on behalf of the Australian Democrats. He certainly spoke in terms which suggested that we were opposing the extension of any assistance to Chamberlain John Deere Pty Ltd. It should be quite clear that the Opposition is proposing that the company should receive assistance in the form of the 25 per cent bounty which was recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission. We are seeking a reduction only in the high level of bounty which is proposed for the current two-year period. There also seemed to be some slight misunderstanding in what Senator Siddons had to say about tractor manufacturing in Australia. In fact, large tractors are manufactured by a number of manufacturers who, to this point, have not been eligible for bounty in most cases. So there is a sector of the industry which is not owned by Chamberlain John Deere and which is currently producing tractors and is producing them profitably.

The basic decision and judgment which had to be made by the Opposition were reasonably well summarised by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in his remarks at the end of the second reading debate. Of course, we have not had access to the total information which has been made available to the Government, but given the losses of recent years, it is not at all clear to the Opposition that after the next two years the tractor manufacturing operation at Chamberlain John Deere will be very different from what it is now. It is not clear that under the lower level of bounty it will be in any sense a more guaranteed profitable operation than it is now. In the absence of that certainty and on the basis of the history of this matter and the examination that has been undertaken by the Commission, it is the view of the Opposition that it would be preferable not to grant the further extension of assistance which the Government is proferring in this legislation. I do not wish to pursue the matter further than that.

I also refer very briefly to some comments which were made by the Minister in his reply. It is all very easy to refer to the need for co-operation in industry. That is a matter on which there is a great deal of common ground; indeed, there is total agreement on it in this chamber. But substantial problems are faced by manufacturing industry which are directly affected by governments, both State and Federal. For example, State governments have a very significant influence on the cost structure of manufacturing industry and, in particular, on labour on-costs through the combination of such things as payroll tax and workers compensation arrangements. I recall discussions with representatives of Chamberlain John Deere in which they referred to the very substantial imposts on the company and pointed out that in the absence of some of those imposts they would be able to avoid the need for taxpayer subsidy.

The Commonwealth also has a very substantial influence on the costs which are loaded onto manufacturing industry. No doubt Senator Button would have heard on the news this morning-it was reported in a number of places-that a recent survey showed that the cost of employment to manufacturing in Australia is very high, compared with our competitors and certainly compared with the United States of America. That is a matter which goes directly to the competitiveness of Australian industry. It is very easy for the Minister to say: `If we worried about that too much, there would be no one to buy the goods which are produced'. The fact of the matter is that the policies of this Government have a singificant influence on some of the elements of costs which afflict manufacturing industry in Australia.

The Minister spoke of my reference to the prices and incomes accord mark 2. In that accord we had the agreement of the Government to forgo its commitment, made as recently as in the last Budget, to argue for the discounting of the consumer price index increases which were caused by the devaluation of the dollar. In the accord mark 2, that Budget commitment was varied. The Government stepped back from it and postponed to next year any argument in favour of discounting. The Government is currently supporting that viewpoint before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is arguing directly in favour of additional wage costs for Australian employers, including companies such as Chamberlain John Deere which are finding competition very difficult. In the same accord mark 2, we find an agreement between the Government and the trade union movement that the problem of on-costs should be further compounded by putting additional obligations on employers with respect to superannuation as a trade-off in the productivity round. Under the terms of that accord an additional three per cent is to be added onto wage costs next year.

It is simply not good enough for Senator Button to say that it is not necessary to deal with these matters. They are a very important part of the problems which are faced by manufacturing industry in this country. It is very important to note that the Government supports a centralised wage fixing system which makes it very difficult for wage arrangements in particular industries to reflect the competitive position those industries face and the profitability they are able to achieve. I think these matters are as fundamental to the future of manufacturing industry in this country as are the equally important matters on which there is such widespread agreement. I can understand the Minister preferring not to deal with those matters. I simply say to him that, in the long term, I do not believe Australia can avoid facing up to some of those important structural difficulties which afflict our industry and make it more difficult for it to be competitive. The sort of co-operation in the work place which has been argued for by Senator Siddons and by others in this debate and adopted by the Minister is a co-operation which has to extend to facing up to the economic realities which confront particular industries, as well as a co-operation in achieving the common objective of producing high quality goods. It is also a common objective to survive in a world which is very competitive and where that competition cannot be avoided.

I have moved these amendments on behalf of the Opposition. It is the view of the Opposition that the Government has not made out its case for going beyond the recommended level of assistance which was put forward by the Industries Assistance Commission. We do not believe that, with the knowledge that is available to us, we can support that proposition. Accordingly, we argue in favour of our amendments and we urge the Committee to adopt them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendments moved by the Opposition. I indicated why earlier. I do not have any hostility to the amendments which have been moved; I cannot think of what else I would have done had I been in opposition. But, as I have said, we had to make a decision about this matter. We believe it important that the industry be given assistance beyound 1990 so that it will be able to plan a little further into the future with a necessary degree of confidence. We also think that the long term rate of bounty proposed by the Industries Assistance Commission is correct. In the next couple of years, when this industry is getting over some very important structural and investment problems it will benefit from the additional bounty level in that period. For those sorts of reasons we do not accept the amendments which have been moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney asked the rhetorical question-I think it was a fair enough question-whether we can be certain that in two years time this industry will be in good shape. Like everything else, of course, it depends on a wide range of issues. I think we can be certain if it rains a lot and the Australian dollar stays much as it is at present. If the Australian dollar appreciates a lot and there is a drought I think we can be quite sure that the company concerned will be in trouble. There are a range of factors which affect that.

I do not wish to be dismissive of the importance of the other matters raised by Senator Chaney. I am fully aware of the very substantial and long term structural problems that this country faces. However, I think it is fair to recognise that Australia will not be a low wage country under any government. We will have to arrive at a competitive situation in that understanding. Many of the most significant manufacturing countries, including Japan, are not low wage countries. They are countries which, by a combination of a variety of policies, produce many more competitive industries than we have. Of course, the question of costs is important in that broad spectrum of issues. I do not think it is correct to say that Australians a high wage country compared with the United States of America across the board. In individual industries where I have have looked at figures that is simply not true. I am talking about productive industries as distinct from the broad level of wages across the United States, in which case this situation might be much truer than in respect of particular industries.

In chastising the Government about these things I think it is important to remember two points: Firstly, earlier in 1985, when we were debating this legislation, real unit labour costs in this country were lower than they had been in any period of our history since 1968; that is to say, real unit labour costs have reverted to that level. Secondly, I think it is important to remember that the profit share of Australian industry is at its highest, certainly since the early 1970s. Those are important factors which have to be remembered in terms of commenting on the Government's attitude to industry and business and the success or otherwise of government policies.

It is not correct, as Senator Chaney said, that the Government broke a commitment in the last Budget. I invite Senator Chaney to read the Budget Statements again. There was no such commitment in the last Budget. There was a commitment in respect of taking into account the effects of the devaluation in the wages system. There was no commitment about devaluation in the September case. If Senator Chaney reads the Budget Statement again he will find that that is quite explicit. He can ask me a question about it tomorrow at Question Time if I am wrong. He should have a look at what the Budget Statement said. What the Government has done is quite consistent with what is in the Budget Statement and there is no breaking of a commitment.

A number of other issues were raised in the course of Senator Chaney's remarks, many of which I agree with. He raised the question of workers compensation on-costs, payroll tax on-costs, and so on. I commend to the New South Wales Government and other governments the steps which have been taken by the Victorian Government in relation to workers compensation. I mention that these steps have been vigorously opposed by the Liberal Party of Australia in Victoria on behalf of the insurance industry. Nonetheless, they are sensible steps which have been well received by industry in Victoria. They have reduced considerably the premiums which will be paid by industry in respect of workers compensation. I believe that the South Australian Government is following that course and I hope that other State governments will do so. So there are a number of things which are important in that regard. The Government does not accept the amendments. We commend the Bills in their original form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply wish to make a comment with respect to one of the last points made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). He said that, if I read the last Budget, I would see quite clearly that the words used are equivocal. But when the matter was pursued post-Budget assurances were given, both in this place and in the House of Representatives, that what was being sought by the Government was a full discounting for the costs of giving rises. The explanation given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and his colleagues was that that was what those words meant and the weasel-words that were used in the Budget were clearly explained to mean that. I think the Minister is simply gilding the lily in this debate and misleading this chamber in a quite obvious way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to draw attention to an article which appeared today in the Australian newspaper. That article, which was written by Alan Fewster, is headed `Government bows on code for South Africa'. I wish to make it clear that what I read in that article is very frightening and disturbing. Having followed this matter very closely over a number of years, I am concerned that we should gain knowledge of this matter by the indirect method of obtaining statements from the Press that the Government has apparently bowed to pressure on this subject. I remind the Senate that some months ago the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) was very quick to trumpet the success of the Government in putting forward a code of conduct which we had not had covering Australian companies and which we should have had for many years. At that stage he made it very clear that the Government was firm in its intention to carry on this undertaking. It should also be made clear that he was aware that there was quite a bit of scepticism, as he mentioned in his speech, by some black South African activists and others about the efficacy of codes of conduct. Consequently, it was fundamental that there should be carried and brought into force a worthwhile and workable scheme-not one which has now obviously become a farce, if one reads what appears in today's newspaper. Since I have not been able to obtain a copy of the code I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the article appearing in today's Australian, 9 October, headed `Government bows on code for South Africa'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Govt bows on code for S Africa
Exclusive by ALAN FEWSTER
THE draft code of conduct for Australian companies trading in South Africa has been watered down following pressure on the Federal Government by business groups.

Guidelines which would require Australian companies to ``take reasonable measures'' to provide their employees in South Africa with certain fringe benefits have been removed, and there is a clear commitment to continued trade with South Africa.

In a draft of the code prepared jointly by the Department of Foreign Affairs and business groups in June, Australian companies were directed to provide leisure and health services, educational and library assistance, housing, welfare, transport and subsidised meals.
Requirements in Section 7 of the code dealing with ``quality of life''. have now either been removed or rewritten in less specific terms.

The Federal Government announced in April that a code of conduct would be established in the absence of comprehensive economic sanctions approved by the United Nations Security Council and observed by South Africa's major trading partners.
The code will apply to Australian companies or their subsidiaries, branches or affiliates operating in, investing in or having representation in South Africa and which employ non-white personnel.
Other changes to the new code, a copy of which The Australian has obtained are:
THE inclusion in the preamble of the sentence: ``While there is no evidence that Australian companies operating in South Africa do not act as good corporate citizens. . .''

A CLEAR commitment that Australian trade with South Africa will continue. The earlier draft read: ``Australian commercial relations with South Africa have been allowed to continue.'' It now reads: ``Australian commercial relations with South Africa will continue.''
Integrate

REMOVAL of the requirement that companies should ``abolish the practice of segregation which is a particularly offensive form of racial discrimination'', and its replacement with a direction that they ``should integrate''.
REMOVAL of the recognition that to fully implement the policy of appointment solely on the basis of ability ``the education disadvantages of non-white employees may need to be compensated for''.
REMOVAL of the requirement that training and development programs should ``facilitate and accelerate'' the movement of non-whites into more senior positions.

REMOVAL of the requirement for companies to provide material assistance and aid to non-white employees adversely affected by the South African labour and residence laws, and its replacement with a direction that they ``should provide advice'' only.

In the draft proposed in June, the section on quality of life began: ``Australian companies operating in South Africa should recognise the particular conditions which affect the living conditions and family situations of non-white employees in the country.

``Companies have social as well as commercial responsibilities in these circumstances and Australian companies there should concern themselves with the quality of life of their employees and their families.''

The latest version of the same section of the code, agreed between the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, and business groups in the past three weeks, reads: ``Australian companies should concern themselves with the quality of life of their employees and their families.
``Recognising that this is not inconsistent with their concern for the welfare of their workforce, companies should aim to provide, in an equitable manner, fringe benefits such as . . .''
The code then lists a number of pension and insurance benefits, but does not include retrenchment benefits, which were part of the earlier draft.
The directions to companies on fringe benefits which have been removed read: ``Companies should also take reasonable measures to assist in:
``Housing of employees with their families, wherever legally possible, close to the place of work.
``Promotion of welfare of employees' families, including their accommodation where families and employees are separated through the legal requirements of the apartheid system.
``Transport of employees where they are disadvantaged by restrictive residence requirements and migrant labour policies.
``The provision of leisure and health service facilities.
``The provision of library and educational assistance, especially for children of employees.
The provision of subsidised nutritious meals to lowly-paid employees.''
Clarification

Business groups are also seeking clarification from the Department of Foreign Affairs over what sanctions an independent administrator who will monitor the code will have to counter non-compliance, and whether his deliberations will come under the Freedom of Information Act.
According to the draft code, ``detailed information provided to the administrator will remain strictly confidential''.
If after consultations with offending businesses, the administrator finds ``an evident intent to continue with non-compliance'' he can report this to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with a statement made by Mr Hayden in the House of Representatives on 18 April and debated in this House a week or fortnight later. I took part in the debate and expressed certain views. In that statement Mr Hayden indicated clearly that it was the intention of the Government to enforce a code of conduct and made it very clear that the Government had been pursuing this matter for many years, as had previous governments. I have had the opportunity of obtaining under the Freedom of Information Act a very great mass of material from the Government and previous governments on their efforts to obtain this code of conduct. The pile which is six inches deep on my table is mostly records of government information. I say to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is in the chamber, that any idea that I am not interested in this matter and that other members of the Opposition are not interested in it would not in any way be correct because we have taken a consistent interest in this matter over many years. Mr Hayden stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government conducted a broad-ranging review of all our relations with South Africa in May 1983.
He went on to say that the Government had finally decided on a voluntary code, not a compulsory code, and stated:

In this context it was decided also that the question should be investigated whether or not a formal, voluntary code of conduct should be observed by Australian companies with commercial interests in South Africa. I wish to announce to honourable members that, as a consequence of this investigation, the Government has decided that such a scheme should be introduced.

Clearly the scheme was definite and it was only a matter of subsequent discussion of details. The idea of having a code of conduct and an investigation of previous codes which existed and still exist among other countries such as the European countries and the United States of America had been gone through and the Government had in mind that this was going to be done and that this would have an effect. He stated:
. . . the introduction of an Australian Code of Conduct will be a positive and productive action.

So it is very important that we recognise that this is not just a piece of cosmetic art on the part of the Government but is, indeed, something which is intended to influence opinion throughout the world. Mr Hayden continues:

There is, however, no Australian requirement for Australian companies to apply any particular practices or employment standards in their business dealings with or in South Africa, although some companies may be covered by the scope of other business codes of conduct. This Code of Conduct is designed to remedy this omission and is in line with action taken by other major trading nations. An Australian Code of Conduct, attuned to the current labour situation in South Africa, will provide support for reformist political change in South Africa.

Can there be any doubt about the intention of the Government to proceed with a code? After discussing the question of a voluntary or compulsory code and agreeing, for the time being, that that voluntary code is one that has to be tried, he stated:

The Code does not require companies to take action outside what can reasonably be considered normal commercial activities or industrial relations practices, nor are companies expected to breach South African laws. For these reasons the Government expects and hopes that the maximum number of companies would agree to adhere to the Code.

I am pleased to see the Acting Foreign Minister here tonight. I trust he will tell us in what way that code was introduced. The idea contained in this document was not one which did not fully carry out the responsibilities of what the Government considered the Australian companies could do. During this speech, Mr Hayden also outlined from paragraphs (a) to (h) the code's provisions and covered the various matters that would be needed, and very desirable matters they are too. He continued:

As the Code will be a voluntary undertaking it is desirable that there be consultations with relevant Australian interest groups, prior to the Code's finalisation, in order to obtain maximum domestic support for it.

That is the only suggestion I can find anywhere that it was not finalised at that stage. Naturally it is a matter on which details should be discussed. Those discussions have gone on obviously to the great discredit of Australia and this Government. We now find the article which appears in today's Australian. I am unable to be given a copy of the proposed amended code. We are told in the Australian-

TALK.START.PARA: —You were offered one on an embargoed basis, weren't you?
—Yes, certainly. I was offered one on an embargoed basis provided I did not use it. That is no use to me.
—You could have seen for yourself whether your indignation was justified.
—I have not come to my indignation yet. We will deal with that in due course, but my view-
—Don't take forever. I can short circuit it.

—The honourable senator will hear the story. I have spoken to his Department and to others this afternoon and tried to get it out of them, but they will not give it up. This article states that the draft code of conduct for Australian companies trading in South Africa has been watered down following pressure on the Federal Government by business groups. The Government has had ample opportunity. This afternoon my staff and I have taken the opportunity to see whether the Department will make available this drafted code which is set out in the article as containing many instances of watering down of the code. For example, there is a requirement in it that matters of quality of life shall be considered. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Requirements in Section 7 of the code, dealing with `quality of life', have now either been removed or rewritten in less specific terms.

. . . requirement for companies to provide material assistance and aid to non-white employees adversely affected by the South African labour and residence laws, and its replacement with a direction that they `should provide advice' only.

So it goes on. I will not repeat the article, because it is already in Hansard. It is clear that that redraft is a shoddy replacement of the existing code which was set down before the Parliament at that time. In the discussions which I have had this afternoon to endeavour to obtain a copy of this document-as the Minister points out, it was offered on the basis that I could not use it elsewhere-

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for your own enlightenment, which would be a positive advance.
—My own enlightenment is a matter of great fascination to me and perhaps to the honourable senator, but this is more important to me.
—It is more important for you to make some grandstanding speech than it is to get at the truth.

—The honourable senator should stop mumbling and listen to something for a change. We should know what is in this code. I am glad to see that the Minister is now fighting with another back bencher and that gives me a brief breath of fresh air. Mr McColl of the Department, to whom my staff member spoke and to whom I subsequently spoke, said that the document is not publicly available but it has been made available to various businesses and other organisations which have been involved in the development of the code. That does not include members of parliament, senators or others. We apparently have no concern in this matter. We were given the original code and now it has been a matter of discussion only with business and other organisations-presumably with trade unions. Apparently someone has disclosed a copy to the Australian; no one knows how it got hold of the copy.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that when I put to Mr McColl that this should be made available to all members of parliament-that we should know what alternative arrangement is now proposed by this Government and what watering down of this proposal has taken place-he said: `The interests of the members of parliament will be taken into account. When the document is completed it will be released and made available to everyone'. I said that that would be a fait accompli. Once the decision is made and the negotiations have finished and we have made fools of ourselves in the eyes of world, we will be expected as members of parliament to come in and look at this matter. In some people's eyes this code of conduct has doubtful prospects of success. It is thought to be not sufficiently strong. But to water it down after announcing it is the worst of all possible worlds.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an utterly false assumption. If you will sit down, I will explain.
—The Minister will have plenty of chances.
—God preserve us from the truth.
—Pull him into line or we will never get home.

—It is all right; let him go on. After being deceived into thinking that the statement would be adopted, we find now that that is not so. One can imagine the anger of black Africans and others concerned with this matter, who are not convinced that codes of conduct are adequate remedies but who will now not be convinced that this Government really means what it says when it talks about codes of conduct or South Africa itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy and Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that Senator Missen should have chosen to foist his indignation on us tonight, following the story in the Australian this morning, because there is no foundation for either; that is to say, there is no justification for Senator Missen's indignation because there is no justification for the terms of the Australian story, with its heading `Government bows on code for South Africa'. Senator Missen would have discovered that for himself had he accepted the offer of the Department of Foreign Affairs to make available a copy of the document to him on his request today. He was offered it, as we have discussed across the chamber, on an embargo basis because the document is not final. Senator Missen chose to stand on his dignity and not accept access to the document on that basis, and as a result he has gone off completely at a tangent tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I set the record straight as follows: I am advised that the code, which is still in draft form and is the subject of discussions with business and trade union representatives, most certainly has not been watered down in the manner suggested by the article. The code continues to require Australian companies to eliminate racial discrimination in their South African operations and establishes a framework in which non-white employees would be employed on a basis no less favourable than that for white employees. The revised version of the codes has been strengthened in some ways over the original draft and now requires companies to support changes to South African laws adversely affecting their employees.

Most of the changes to the code which are under consideration at the moment, including those reported in the Australian, are simply drafting changes designed to tighten the wording without affecting the substance of the code. For example, provision of standard fringe benefits remains a requirement of the code, although specific reference to retrenchment benefits is omitted. It is omitted because such benefits are already included in the remuneration indicator used in the code. There is, in any event, provision for contributory unemployment insurance. Other benefits, such as housing and transport, are not obligatory, but the revised draft does include a specific reference to the setting aside of funds for such purposes.

The article is also misleading when it notes the removal of a reference to facilitated and accelerated movements of non-whites into more senior positions. The code continues to require companies to implement programs which encourage the movement of non-whites into such positions. Finally, the article is incorrect in its assertion that the revised code does not require companies to provide aid in relation to legal matters. It is obviously the desire of the Government to settle the final shape of this code as soon as possible after the consultative process that we have set in train with business and trade unions is completed.

I will consult with Mr Hayden on his return to determine when it might be possible and appropriate to make public the full text of the revised code, but in the meanwhile I hope that we do not get a repetition of the mischievously false stories of the kind which appeared in the Australian this morning and the mischievously false indignation that unhappily we have been treated to tonight by Senator Missen on an entirely false premise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September a question was asked in this place of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in relation to home loans and loan service fees. The issue was raised by Senator Haines. The relevant matters which were discussed in the question and answer on that date were as follows: The Government has for some time had a ceiling on housing loan bank interest rates. That ceiling is currently 13.5 per cent. Senator Walsh stated in his reply that there are no Government proposals to alter that ceiling. The Minister for Finance said that some financial institutions at that time were charging the regulated ceiling of 12.5 per cent. Others apparently were not, 13.5 per cent being suggested as the lowest interest then applying.

SPEECH.PARA: A further matter raised was the service charge which some banks are now levying on their customers. Those fees, which have been introduced recently, vary. For the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia, they range from $30 to $90 a year for mortgages from $1,000 to $100,000. For loans over the latter sum higher loan service fees are payable. As far as I could understand on 10 September, the thrust of Senator Haines's question was not directed at the actual amount of the service charge, even though that was an important consideration. What appeared to be more important was that some financial institutions might be using the loan service fee as a back-door method of thwarting the Government's intention of keeping home loan bank interest rates at a maximum of 13.5 per cent. If that was the major thrust of the question, the Minister did not address that matter in great detail.

Following complaints which I have received from Queensland residents, I intend to speak on this matter as well. There seems to be a fair amount of evidence that at least one bank-probably there are others-has introduced a loan service fee with the aim of thumbing its nose at the 13.5 per cent interest rate ceiling which has been set by the Government. My comments refer specifically to the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia, but probably apply equally to other financial institutions. Those who have home loans from the bank are now paying 13.5 per cent interest. In addition, they have now been served notice that they will pay a loan service fee which will be levied half-yearly. Anyone with an oustanding balance of $30,000, for instance, will be required to pay an extra fee of $70 per year. To my mind, and certainly to the minds of my constituents who have approached me, this is nothing but a deliberate ploy to counter the 13.5 per cent ceiling set by the Government. For the Government's own instrumentality to do this is appalling behaviour.
Those who have approached me have received a circular letter entitled `Loan Service Fee'. In part, the letter states:
Due to the continually rising costs of maintaining and servicing home loan accounts, we have found it necessary to introduce a small Loans Service Fee to offset these expenditures.

The letter goes on to mention that the fee will be levied half-yearly and mentions the actual charges, some of which I mentioned earlier. I find it hard to believe that the claim of `continually rising costs of maintaining and servicing accounts' is truthful. Has the extensive use of computers in the banking industry increased costs? Surely costs should decrease as computers continue to take over tasks that were previously performed manually; or is the claim of rising costs an admission of inefficiency? Perhaps to some extent it is, but is more likely that it is a spurious claim to camouflage a strategy aimed at circumventing the 13.5 per cent ceiling. I do not intend to burden Hansard by seeking to incorporate the text of the Commonwealth Savings Bank letter. However, I seek leave to table a copy of the text in case it is of use to honourable senators.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. When the Minister for Finance spoke on this matter on 10 September, he remarked that the service fee represented only a small increase in the interest rate which the borrowers are paying. This is acknowledged, but I must mention two points: Firstly, an extra commitment of $50 or $70 a year is a real burden on many of the constituents whom I represent. It is far too easy to sit here in the Senate chamber and forget the daily struggles faced by some people out in the real Australia. An extra burden of the type I mentioned can make this struggle even more severe. If I may digress for a moment, I should say that when I first entered this chamber, this was one of the particular groups which I expected a Labor government would protect. I still expect it to do so. Secondly, I would need great persuasion to be convinced that the bank which I mentioned is not like the tax evader, trying to find loopholes in the government directive that the ceiling be 13.5 per cent for housing loan bank interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said on 10 December:
The Government will keep under review the home loan service charge to ensure that it is not used as a surrogate interest rate increase.

I ask the Minister and the Government not only to keep these charges under review but to scrutinise them carefully at this stage. A fundamental question is whether the loan service fees can be justified, especially as banks operated without them prior to this. I ask the Government to address this question as well.

There is little, if any, pain for a large corporation to increase its charges when its customers are locked in, cannot go elsewhere and must pay whatever is charged. For those having to pay, however, there are difficulties and if I have to take sides, it will be on the side of the consumer. It may be too much to ask the banks to look at their own consciences, but I do ask them to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the matter which was brought up last night by Senator Bolkus and deal with some of his claims. I did not obtain the documents from Hansard until late this afternoon. Since then I have contacted the office of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to ask it to expedite the answer to question No. 412 on the Notice Paper which relates to this matter. I am also in the process of obtaining a number of documents which I believe will refute totally any and all of the claims made in this place last night by Senator Bolkus against Don Chisholm. At this stage I have managed to obtain two documents but in order to obtain a number of other documents from the Government I may be required to make application under the Freedom of Information Act. I will then be able to prove conclusively, with attested documents from the Government, that the statements which Senator Bolkus made were in fact false and unchecked.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike Senator Bolkus, I believe in checking my facts and in having firm documentation before coming forward in the Senate. I believe it is extremely important to refute the types of bogus claims that Senator Bolkus has made. I wish to reaffirm my conviction of Don Chisholm's integrity. He has been involved in business for 20 years, and I am obtaining a set of references from his previous employers to that point. He has been unemployed since he left the Birdwood Mill, approximately four years ago, except for the period when he was involved in the community employment program with Adelaide Community and Educational Television.

I would like to deal with some of the claims that I can currently refute on the available documentation. The first of these is the claim that Donald Chisholm was involved in the Board of ACE Television at the time he was in its employ. I seek leave to incorporate two documents in Hansard. The first is dated 27 April 1984 and is a letter of resignation from Don Chisholm to Mr Rick Coy, who was Chairman of ACE Television.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
The Chairman,
Ace-TV Inc.
Dear Mr Coy,
This is to confirm my acceptance of the position of Executive Officer. I will endeavour to continue to the work we have all done towards Public Television.
It is only proper that I should submit my resignation as a Director before taking up this position and I trust that the Board will accept this as my resignation.
I look forward to the next twelve months and hope that we can obtain our objectives.
Thank you and kind regards.
Donald Chisholm

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that these two documents prove beyond doubt that Don Chisholm in fact was not a member of the Board of ACE Television at the time he was an employee of that organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The next claim made by Senator Bolkus was that Mr Chisholm had set up a trust in some way to defraud people.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said it himself.

—He certainly did not say that he had set up a trust to defraud people. Firstly I must correct that whole idea. Senator Bolkus should check his facts. A trust was set up by Mr Chisholm's father in 1978, long before ACE Television or the CEP grants were under any type of consideration and while Mr Chisholm was an employee of the Birdwood Mill in South Australia. I am getting copies of the trust deed and various documents so that the relevant information can be incorporated to prove these facts. Mr Chisholm has assured me of them-I am getting taxation returns for both himself and his de facto companion, Wendy McPherson, to prove that Donald Chisholm in no way benefited from the trust while either receiving unemployment benefit or being in the employ of ACE Television. Unfortunately, because of the time scale, I do not have these documents today. I will return to this in the Senate once I have the full documentation. I will seek to incorporate the relevant documents in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Another claim was that while Donald Chisholm was employed he had Wendy McPherson working. Wendy McPherson has on several occasions taken up casual work with the Birdwood Post Office and, I understand, with several other organisations, sometimes on a voluntary basis. The employment at the Post Office was on a paid basis. All of this has been fully declared to the Department of Social Security and I am currently seeking documents to prove this and, as I have said, the requisite taxation forms which I believe will prove conclusively that no defrauding of either the Government or anybody else has been carried out by Donald Chisholm or Wendy.

Some rather strange claims were made concerning Donald Chisholm receiving unemployment benefit while campaigning. In fact, as I understand it now, Donald Chisholm is not in receipt of unemployment benefit. Up until the time when his candidacy was confirmed, he was in fact available for work and registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service. I understand that Wendy McPherson, who is not currently casually working, is on unemployment benefit. Neither of them is in receipt of any money from any other source. I am obtaining documentary evidence to support this statement, so that I can table it in the Parliament.

I fail also to understand Senator Bolkus's paranoia about ACE Television. He states that ACE Television was set up with some type of aim to subvert the introduction of the Special Broadcasting Service in South Australia. I fail to see how it could ever have achieved such an end or could ever have been set up for such a purpose, and it seems to be a very strange claim by Senator Bolkus. I must say that ACE Television has as members and as correspondent organisations a number of very well respected Adelaide institutions, such as the University of Adelaide, Flinders University and the South Australian College of Advanced Education. That is on the educational side. We also have support, and people involved in the Board, from the Ethnic Communities Council and from the United Ethnic Council. People from both councils have been involved in our meetings and in consultations with us over the years. We also have a very strong community base from production houses and community organiations that are interested in putting forward their views. No organisation that is involved in this is interested in subverting the SBS, and our relations with SBS are very cordial.

The whole of this attack on Donald Chisholm has political motivation, obviously, and I believe that it is a misuse of the Senate. I deplore Senator Bolkus's attempt to smear a citizen of Australia under privilege. If he wished to raise points here, he should have checked his facts before coming here. I shall prove that it is possible to check those facts and to get documented information. Once I have all those attested facts, Mr President, I shall be returning to present the documents to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take up too much time in responding to Senator Vigor's remarks. I should like to make two very quick points. The first one, although trivial, is in respect of Adelaide Community and Educational Television. I never claimed that it was set up with the purpose of subverting the Special Broadcasting Service, but its activities at the time of crucial decision-making period for the introduction of SBS into Adelaide were such that, if successful, they would have undermined the introduction of that service there.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to Donald Chisholm, I stand very much by the substance of the allegations that I made yesterday. It is my belief that on the basis of his own confessions in newspaper articles and other material that I have seen, Donald Chisholm should not have an entitlement. His position with respect to the ACE Television Board was one of such close proximity that he should have precluded himself from obtaining the job, considering also the fact that under the stated aims of the community employment program he was not in one of those categories of persons who should have been given priority.

In respect to the second aspect, the unemployment benefit, I do not feel that I have been swayed at all by Senator Vigor's bombastic defence this evening of a very close ally. I shall just wait until the Government investigates the matter and the right course is taken.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
